title: By Adverse Winds. [A novel.]
author: Smeaton, William Henry Oliphant.
snippet: "Yes, they have a beautiful old house in Grange Loan,and keep up a considerable amount of style."

title: By Adverse Winds. [A novel.]
author: Smeaton, William Henry Oliphant.
snippet: The carriage drove along Grange Loan, then into theCausewayside, finaUy through Powburn, thus taking what iscaUed " the old road" to Liberton. At the foot of the hdlcrowned by the old parish church with its quadrilateralsteeple, stands the httle hamlet called Liberton Dams—sonamed from the storage tanks of the Edinburgh WaterCompany, some eighty or a hundred years ago, being locatedthere.

title: By Adverse Winds. [A novel.]
author: Smeaton, William Henry Oliphant.
snippet: Mr.Armitage insisted I should go home with him to his aunt,who keeps house for his father, the Professor. Theylive in a beautiful mansion in Grange Loan. I had to acceptthe offer.

title: By Adverse Winds. [A novel.]
author: Smeaton, William Henry Oliphant.
snippet: Through this medium, thehappy possessor could see all that was transpiring at themoment on any spot of the globe he chose. Through thepantiscope of the novelist, in like manner, I would ask thereader, wheresoever he be, to observe, in the highway termedGrange Loan, but standing well back from the lodge-gates,within spacious and wooded grounds, a certain large, oldfashioned, whitewashed family mansion. Ramblingly irregularwas it in every part, with its quaint crow-stepped gables andcorner turrets, its clustered chimneys and long narrow windowsheavily mullioned and " transomed," all betokening the hybridstyle of architecture prevalent in Scotland when last centurywas in its teens.
